context: Common forms of antibiotic misuse include excessive use of <a0_0><b5_0>prophylactic antibiotics<b5_0/><a0_0/> in travelers and <a1_0><b6_0>failure of medical professionals to prescribe the correct dosage<b6_0/><a1_0/> of antibiotics on the basis of the patient's weight and history of prior use. Other forms of misuse include <a2_0><b7_0>failure to take the entire prescribed course of the antibiotic, incorrect dosage and administration, or failure to rest for sufficient recovery<b7_0/><a2_0/>. <a3_0><b8_0>Inappropriate antibiotic treatment<b8_0/><a3_0/>, for example, is their prescription to treat viral infections such as the common cold. One study on respiratory tract infections found "physicians were more likely to <a4_0><b9_0>prescribe antibiotics<b9_0/><a4_0/> to patients who appeared to expect them". Multifactorial interventions aimed at both physicians and patients can reduce inappropriate prescription of antibiotics.
